Award.AwardTitle: Quantifying Risk of Tree Species Regeneration Failure and Ecosystem Transitions in Lower Elevation Forests

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Ecological disturbances have the potential of causing transitions of low-elevation forests into other ecosystem types, consequently altering the position of lower treelines. Small shifts in these lower treelines can result in large changes in forested area, which will have profound ecological and economic impacts for society. These ecosystems already are experiencing dramatic changes due to widespread disturbance and climate-driven mortality with long-term implications for ecosystem services including water management, carbon stocks, and maintenance of connectivity for wildlife species. This research project will provide new perspectives, information, insights and approaches to advance basic understanding about the processes that maintain low-elevation forests and improve capabilities to forecast where and under what conditions these forests may be lost. The project will provide critical information for identifying vulnerable low-elevation forested regions, including those in the wildland-urban interface. The findings will provide a novel but tractable means of quantifying risk of regeneration failure and ecosystem transition in lower-elevation forests to guide future land use and management priorities in the wildland-urban interface of the western U.S. Project results will provide valuable information and insights for policy makers, governmental agencies, and resource administrators in assessing appropriate courses of action to minimize socio-economic and ecological impacts.

Ecosystem transitions at lower elevation forests can occur because of both mortality of adult trees and regeneration failure after disturbance. Increases in temperature and the frequency of drought may prevent seedling regeneration at sites that adult trees can generally tolerate. The investigators will explore answers to the core question of how climate and ecological disturbances impact tree species emergence and regeneration in lower-elevation forests. They will identify regions prone to regeneration failure by linking fine-scaled physiological greenhouse studies to broad-scale observational data of species regeneration patterns as mediated through local and regional climate and hydrology models. It will assess geographic patterns in the demography of lower treelines by using forest inventory data, and mechanistic and correlative niche models of species distributions. The investigators will identify vulnerable areas for active management and improve basic understanding of processes governing the distribution of lower-treeline forests by bridging the disciplines of biogeography, biophysical ecology, and ecohydrology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project assessed the  likelihood that drought will drive the loss of low elevation forests of the western US thus altering the position of the lower treeline. Typically most land surface in a region is at low and moderate elevation. Thus, small shifts in the lower treeline can result in large changes in forested area with profound ecological and economic consequences for society. This project identified regions prone to tree regeneration failure by linking fine-scaled physiological greenhouse studies of seedling mortality to broad-scale observational data of species regeneration patterns as mediated through local and regional climate and hydrology.  We assessed geographic patterns in the demography of low elevation forests using forest inventory data, and mechanistic and empirical models of tree regeneration. We show that cumulative drought stress, and its legacy and consequences for seedling mortality is predictable and can be modeled at local to landscape scales.For example, we found that simulated mortality in seedlings correlated with the current distribution of forest cover near the lower treeline, suggesting that drought stress limits tree regeneration and ultimately constrains the low-elevation extent of conifer forests. Additionally, we show that at dry sites across the western US, seasonal to annual climate conditions over the past 20 years have become increasingly unsuitable for regeneration. Together, our results demonstrate that climate change combined with high severity fire is leading to increasingly fewer opportunities for seedlings to establish after wildfires and may lead to ecosystem transitions in low-elevation forests across the western US. Our study provides a critical link between climate change and recent observations of reduced post-fire tree regeneration in low elevation forests of the western US.

 

This research improves our knowledge about the processes that maintain low elevation forests and improves our capacity to forecast where and under what conditions these forests may be lost. This information is critical for identifying vulnerable low elevation forested regions of the western U.S that may benefit from post-disturbance restoration and replanting, including those in the wildland-urban interface. This project also supported the education and training of a postdoctoral researcher, two graduate students, and several undergraduate students in STEM disciplines. Lastly, this research garnered public attention and was highlighted in multiple news outlets including CNN and BBC.
